0.46.text:
It's the Friday night favourite; the dish
you can eat without using a knife and fork

6.02.text:
and its Britain's most loved and most
popular take away.

9.42.text:
It's fish and chips. But did you know: It
was at the beginning of Queen Victoria's reign

14.61.text:
fried fish began being sold as leftovers
to the working classes

18.11.text:
at London's Billingsgate market.
Alexis Sawyer, the celebrity chef of the time

22.97.text:
used to eat it with his fingers
on the way home from work.

26.56.text:
When Charles Dickens's Oliver Twist said:
"Please sir, can I have some more?"

30.89.text:
- he could easily have been referring to
our favourite dish. Dickens mentions a

34.98.text: fried fish warehouse in Oliver Twist.

37.97.text:
During this time fish would be served
with either bread or baked potatoes.

42.53.text:
It's a north-south divide; debate and counterclaim
surrounds the answer to the question:

46.98.text: "Who opened the first fish and chip shop?"

50.00.text:
Some say it was Jewish immigrant Joseph
Malin who opened one in Cleveland Street in

55.05.text:
Others say it was entrepreneur John Lees
who sold fish and chips out of a wooden hut

61.81.text:
Fish and chips became popular as a
late-night post-pub feast for men,

65.41.text:
before becoming
the time-saving mid-day meal of factory

68.40.text:
and foundry workers, as well as a
pay-day treat for families

71.59.text: at the end to the working week

73.82.text:
Four pence in today's money is what it
would have cost you to sit down at the

77.29.text:
first fish and chip restaurant, owned by Sam
Isaacs

79.43.text:
in Whitechapel in London and be served
bread-and-butter and tea with your fish and chips.

84.44.text:
By 1910 there around 25,000 fish and chip
shops in Britain.

90.21.text:
Did fish and chips help to win the First World
War?

92.73.text:
It was seen as a hot, tasty
and morale-boosting meal.

95.85.text:
Prime Minister Lloyd George's War Cabinet
recognised its importance,

99.16.text:
and because of this, safeguarded
supplies and kept prices low.

103.10.text:
In the inter-war years, two thirds of the
British wet fish caught

106.61.text:
were used to supply the growing
fish and chip industry.

110.08.text:
The number fish and chip shops reached its
peak at 35,000

114.66.text:
Author George Orwell wrote in 'The Road to
Wigan Pier' that

117.60.text:
'fish and chips were first among home
comforts and kept the masses happy'.

122.36.text:
At this time there was a fish and chip
shop on the corner of most streets in the UK

126.12.text:
and the dish was becoming a firm favourite
for seaside day-trippers and holidaymakers.

131.80.text:
During the second world war, ministers made
sure that

134.15.text:
fish and chips were one of the few foods that
weren't rationed.

136.88.text:
Meanwhile the deep-sea trawling industry
also played a key part during wartime,

141.58.text:
as experienced seamen were highly sought after
by the navy.

145.50.text:
Curry and spice and all things nice
- including fish and chips.

150.25.text:
During the revolution and social change in
the 1960s,

153.51.text:
take-away food blended, as Chinese and
Asian restaurants put their own version of

157.23.text: fish and chips on the menu.

159.47.text:
Wrapped in the day's newspaper; that's how
people before the 80s

162.53.text:
enjoyed their  takeaway fish and chips.
This ended when it was ruled

166.29.text:
unsafe for the food to come into contact with
newspaper ink.

170.26.text:
The first fish and chip awards, organised
to honour the tastiest

174.03.text:
and the best in the industry, took place in
London.

177.29.text:
Seven million portions of fish and chips are
consumed

179.87.text:
every week in the UK; 380 million portions
a year.

185.13.text:
There are 8 fish and chip shops to every McDonald's
restaurant in the UK,

188.48.text: and now the dish has gone global.

190.39.text:
It's a favourite around the world and a must-have
on the bucket list for visitors to the UK.
